Title: The Role of Consciousness in Adaptive Behavior: A Combined Empirical, Computational, and Robot-Based Approach (Conscious Distributed Adaptive Control, CDAC)

This project aims to elucidate the functional role of consciousness in adaptive behavior, a long-standing paradox in cognitive science. The CDAC project will employ a multidisciplinary approach, combining empirical, computational, and robot-based methods to investigate the neural principles underlying conscious adaptive behavior. Our central hypothesis is that a shift towards intentional agent-dominated worlds requires novel control architectures that incorporate consciousness. We propose to develop parallel and distributed control loops for real-time operation, with a second level of control for coherence and conscious scene construction. This conscious scene is hypothesized to enable functions such as credit assignment and planning beyond immediate information.

The project's objectives are threefold: to resolve the paradox of consciousness and action, identify neuronal principles of consciousness, and construct a neuromorphic robot-based real-time conscious architecture. Expected outcomes include a framework advancing beyond the state of the art, system-level models of conscious architecture, computational studies of the neuronal substrate, and empirical validation with both humanoid robots and stroke patients. The project's relevance extends to advancing our understanding of the mind and brain, providing new neurorehabilitation technologies, and contributing to the development of robots with advanced social competence. By exploring the role of consciousness in adaptive behavior, CDAC will contribute significantly to our understanding of this complex and multifaceted phenomenon.
